title: 104_hr3099
content: The Act titled "Washita Battlefield National Historic Site Act of 1996" is established for the Washita Battlefield National Historic Site. The Congress finds that the Battle of the Washita in 1868 was a significant engagement between Plains tribes and the US Army, led by Lt. Colonel Custer, resulting in over 150 Indian casualties. The battle symbolizes the tribes' struggle to maintain their traditional lifeways and the site remains culturally intact. The Cheyenne village site at the Battle of the Washita has not been significantly altered except by periodic flooding of the Washita River. The purposes of the Act are to recognize the battle as a nationally significant event in frontier military history and to establish the site as a national historic site, involving American Indian groups in planning and educational programs. The establishment of the site at the Battle of the Washita as a national historic site is the main purpose of the Act. The Washita Battlefield National Historic Site is established in Oklahoma to preserve and interpret the Battle of the Washita. It consists of approximately 326 acres and private lands under conservation easements. A map of the site is on file with the National Park Service. The Secretary of the Interior has the authority to make minor revisions to the boundary of the Washita Battlefield National Historic Site in accordance with the Land and Water Conservation Act of 1965. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION. The Secretary manages the national historic site in accordance with applicable laws and for purposes of protecting and preserving the site's features and interpreting its resources. The Secretary manages the national historic site to interpret its cultural and natural resources for public understanding and appreciation, consulting regularly with the Cheyenne-Arapaho Tribe and entering into cooperative agreements to further the purposes of the Act. SEC. 5. ACQUISITION OF PROPERTY. Within the national historic site boundaries, the Secretary can acquire lands through donation, purchase, or exchange with owner consent. Conservation easements will be held by the State of Oklahoma to preserve the site's integrity. The easements aim to maintain private ownership and agricultural use of the land within the national historic site boundaries. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. Within five years, the Secretary will prepare a general management plan for the national historic site, addressing resource protection, visitor use, research, curation, highway signing, and involvement of the Cheyenne-Arapaho Tribe and other entities in educational programs. Authorization of appropriations for this Act is set at $5,000,000.
